captions.text:
CHRIS HARRIS: Welcome to Leipzig
for this 918 job.

This really is a fly on the
wall-style thing, but it is a
hectic day.
It's a fair few journalists.

We haven't got much
time in the car.
We've just had a presentation.
This is interesting.

I think we all suspected that
when the P1 and the LaFerrari

were launched that Porsche
would have to respond.

Well, they have just responded,
because the claimed

power figures for this
car are as follows.

From the internal combustion
engine, 608 horsepower, and it
revs to over 9,000.

The total power figure though--
this is mindboggling,
excuse my pieces of paper--

887 horsepower from a dry weight
of 1640 kilograms.

The 918 has come to meet the
other two somewhat in terms of
performance.

I think we're going to
mill around a bit.

We'll have a look at some of
the technology in the car,

because there's some lovely use
of materials as well as

some pioneering technologies
in there that we
need to look at.

And then, hopefully, we'll get
a ride with Walter who will

show us how to drive the circuit
at Leipzig, and then
we get, I think, three laps.

How can you tell anything
in three laps?
You probably can't.

But do you want to be the
journalist that says, no, I

don't want to drive your car,
because I only get three laps?
No, you don't.

A hectic day, but hopefully
a fun one.

Some of the interesting stuff
that's going on here.
The dashboard.

They felt the dashboard
panel would be
too heavy in aluminium.
Say that to yourself.
Too heavy in aluminium.

Most sports car manufacturers
boast about using aluminium.

So, what they've done is they've
galvanized carbon
fiber with metal.

So, effectively, you've got this
covering on carbon fiber.

It's a freakish thing, because
you pick it up expecting the

weight of aluminium, and
it weighs nothing.

It's like light titanium
almost.

We've got a carbon fiber roll
bar here, stabilizer bar.

I mean, this stuff
is expensive.

It's also utterly beautiful
to the touch.
This is interesting.

Obviously the car has a carbon
tire, just like the Carrera GT

did 10 years ago and all the
main rivals do as well.

But, our other support points,
where you're hanging

components from anything--
engine, suspension, and a lot

of the electrical gubbins that
goes into the car-- normally

those support brackets are
made of aluminium.

So it's rather disappointing
that you take a lovely light

carbon structure and then
attach this rather ugly,
heavy, aluminium bit.

Porsche is using force carbon,
so there's a bit there.

That's the equivalent
to the aluminium.

There's definitely a
weight reduction.

It's not as profound as with
the dashboard, but it just

shows that they tried
to peel weight
everywhere from this car.
Everywhere.

But then you look at the
headline figure, 1640, and you

think, that's still
quite a lump.

I find this side of the car
quite confusing, because I

just keep saying to myself,
well, take the bloody electric
motor out of it then.

Then it would weigh 1,100
kilograms, and we'd have 610

horsepower just from
that lovely engine.

Electricity seems to
spoil sports cars.

Anyhow, I'll get over
that in a minute.
Let's go over here.

The battery cells are vast
and, for me, very

controversial in a
car of this type.

They're lithium ion with a
nominal voltage of 385 volts,
peaking at 430 volts.
[GRUNTING]
CHRIS HARRIS: That's 18 cells.

This is, perhaps, here, the
key paradox of the 918.

You have to lump these cells
around, and in doing so, you

have to make incredible weight
savings in other areas.

So central to my argument's
always been, make the
incredible weight savings.

Don't lump these things
around with you.

They make good dumbbells
though.

And there are dozens of
other cool things
going on in the 918.

The 4.6 liter v8 is completely
beltless with
integrated oil pumps.

Power output is 608 horsepower,
augmented by the

electric motors to make a
total of 887 horsepower.

Peak torque is over 920
foot-pounds, and from idle to

7,000 RPM, there is
never less than
590 foot-pounds available.

The top exit exhaust
is pure inconel.
This is quite a strange event.

We're now waiting to have a go
in the car, but before that,

there's a chance of a ride
with Walter Rohrl
in a 4.0 liter RS.
Watch this now.

This is Walter demonstrating how
to go around the circuit.

A strange choice of car and
person when you're trying to

make your hybrid super car
or hybrid car look really

interesting, because the 4.0
liter RS is pounding around

making a much better
noise than a 918
Spyder at the moment.

I think we're going to get
three laps at most.

It's soaking wet, and I'm led
to believe that the car

behaves like two wheel drive
when it oversteers.

If they think I'm oversteering
their 20 million pound

development model, then
I'm not going to.

I'm slightly concerned, but
we're going to get three laps,

so that's better than
nothing, isn't it?

Curb weight is now 1640
kilograms, which, given the

mass of the battery packs,
is mighty impressive.

But it's still a lot heavier
than either the LaFerrari or
the McLaren P1.

The optional Weissach
package shaves 40
kilograms from that figure.

According to project chief Frank
Walliser, the chassis

calibration is 80% finished
for the complicated torque

vectoring system, and the power
train is even closer to
final specification.

Active aerodynamics can open
flaps in the front intakes and

alter the rear wing angle
to improve drag or
downforce as required.

And we also have some claimed
performance figures.
Sit tight, everyone.

0 to 62 in 2.8, 0 to 124 miles
an hour in 7.9, and 0 to 186
in 23 seconds dead.

They look very brisk indeed,
until you scrutinize the P1
and the LaFerrari.

The P1 and the LaFerrari are
both sub 3 seconds to 62 miles

an hour, they're both sub 7
seconds to 124, and above

that, it looks bad, because the
P1 is claimed to do 0 to

186 in 17 seconds, and the
LaFerrari in 15.5.

That's 15.5 versus the
Porche's 23 dead.

OK, so I'm going to talk
you through this.

I'm in full electric
mode, and I have--

What sort of performance
do I have?

I feel like I have the
performance of something like

a Cayenne diesel is
what it feels.
Or maybe a Panamera diesel.
I put my foot flat down.
The engine comes on.
FRANK WALLISER: Too much.
CHRIS HARRIS: Too much.
So that's the kick.
OK.

How do I get it back
to electric?

FRANK WALLISER: Just
slow down.
CHRIS HARRIS: Slow down?
That's really clever.
OK.
So it's on the throttle.
FRANK WALLISER: Yes.

The idea was everything on the
brake pedal, throttle--

CHRIS HARRIS: So you don't
need to play with
the steering wheel?
FRANK WALLISER: No.
CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah, OK.
I get that.

I can see why, as an owner,
you'd-- because if you drive

the car regularly, you'll
get used to it.
OK, that's clever.
So, yeah.
I've got--

that's a good amount
of performance.

You could take care of ordinary
cars with that amount
of performance.
And what's the maximum speed?

FRANK WALLISER: 150 kilometers
per hour.

CHRIS HARRIS: So just over
90, 95 miles an hour.

OK, this circuit is flat and a
little bit featureless, but I

think we found a little
bit of rhythm there.
Here's a little chicane here.

Brake pedal, that's
interesting.

So it's a little bit Citroen in
that you've got to get your
foot down a little bit.
So I click one more?

FRANK WALLISER: One click,
then you're a hybrid.
CHRIS HARRIS: Now I'm hybrid.
FRANK WALLISER: [INAUDIBLE].
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: That's
interesting.

FRANK WALLISER: This is only
the combustion engine.

CHRIS HARRIS: This is just the
combustion engine now.

FRANK WALLISER: Either
combustion
engine or electric motors.
It's not combined.
CHRIS HARRIS: OK.
So, let's get up to--
car feels quite supple.

It's got a lot of
mechanical grip.

Gearbox is quick, steering
is nice.

Driving position feels unnatural
to start with.
FRANK WALLISER: [INAUDIBLE].

CHRIS HARRIS: So now we have
full engine power and we have

full electric power
as well, yes?
It's sport mode.
FRANK WALLISER: Sport mode.
CHRIS HARRIS: Fourth gear.
That's a lot of performance.
It's a lot of performance.

The brake feel is a bit
funny coming into
some of these turns.

For continuity's sake,
we've had to
stop and change cameras.

So, it's now a little
bit greasy, but
the performance is--
it's big.

It's bigger than I thought
it would be as well.

The handling, well, that's
interesting, because the car

doesn't feel anything like as
heavy as the claimed weight.

It doesn't have the
inertia at all.
Steering's very direct.
It's a very interesting car.
Very interesting car.

And the noise, well, miles
better than when
I first drove it.
Miles better.

Now, this is the raciest
mode of all.
The tire is really impressive.

It's a special Michelin that
has a kind of energy

construction with
a soft compound.

And I have to say, that's one of
the most impressive things
about the car.

And also, it's interesting
now.

I've got a little bit of spots
of rain coming, so I can feel
the balance of the car.

The torque vectoring, the
chassis working hard.

I mean, it's not a finished
item yet, but wow.

And now flat out,
listen to that.
Whoo!

Better stop a bit earlier,
better stop a bit earlier.

I think we got the braking
distance right then.
We tip it in, we clip an apex.
Oh, yes.
It's a mid-engine sports car.

I think the most complimentary
thing I can say is that when

I'm pushing on, it doesn't feel
like I'm driving a hybrid
sports car.

It feels like I'm driving a
mid-engine sports car, because

I'm not aware of the electric
charge coming through.

Oh, there's definitely stuff
to be thinking about here.

Oh, Frank, I wanted to ask you
some questions about the

chassis, because it's such
a complicated chassis.

If we're in race mode and I exit
a corner, I'm in the exit

phase, and I'm in full
power in second gear,
8,000 RPM on the motor.
What percentage of--

what have I got going where,
in terms of if I had 880
horsepower available?

FRANK WALLISER: Roughly, a rough
calculation is 15% to
20% of the total of--
CHRIS HARRIS: OK, cool.
That makes sense.

Is this new output that we've
learned about today, is that a

response to what we saw in
Geneva from Porsche--
from Ferrari and from McLaren?

FRANK WALLISER: No, this is not
possible to do something
in two months.

It was always built
in the car.
CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah.

FRANK WALLISER: Well, we are,
maybe have some competitors,

and so I think it's
better not to tell
everything in the beginning.

We tell the figures
and the final
numbers when we are sure.

We when approved everything,
this is now, and so we could

just tell now the
final numbers.
Not [INAUDIBLE].

CHRIS HARRIS: I found lots
about the car really
interesting and unexpected.

One thing that I suppose, given
that this is a work in

progress, we have to
accept that this is
not a finished car.
FRANK WALLISER: Not finished.

CHRIS HARRIS: Quite something to
be able to drive it before
it's finished.

The braking feels like,
this is something
that's going to be--

I'm sure you'll get it right,
but at the moment, we have a

sort of slight step
in the pedal.
FRANK WALLISER: Exactly.

CHRIS HARRIS: And is this a
calibration thing, or is this

just actually physically getting
the pedal to work?

FRANK WALLISER: No,
it's not physical.
It's just calibration.
CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah.

FRANK WALLISER: This is the fine
tuning we talked about.
What the car needs.

Here's now a problem with cars,
wheels and everything,

tires in the latest
specification.

Then you can work on the fine
tuning, to have the linearity

that you need in
a brake pedal.

Because at the moment,
the step is not nice.

But we're working on it,
and it will be done
for the final car.

CHRIS HARRIS: How many control
units are there in this car?
How many individual boxes?

FRANK WALLISER: We count
55 in our architecture.
CHRIS HARRIS: 55?
FRANK WALLISER: 55.

Considering also the oral
control unit, and the switch

for the headlights as
a control unit.

CHRIS HARRIS: And are they
control units used by Porsche
in other cars?
FRANK WALLISER: Yeah, yeah.

We have on the chassis side, we
have some takeovers, like
in the doors.

We have, of course for
the engine, it's new.

For the PDK, it's an existing
control unit, but we're

developing on the software side,
the power control units

are new, and the software
battery management system.

There we have a linkage to the
Panamera plug-in hybrid.

But there's also some new things
like the control unit
for the aerodynamics.

CHRIS HARRIS: Which
is entirely new.
FRANK WALLISER: Yeah.
CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah.
FRANK WALLISER: [INAUDIBLE].

CHRIS HARRIS: This
is not a question
necessary, for you to answer.

And I'm not trying
to wind you up.

Are there 918 people
for this car?

It seems to me that I can
understand the reasons why
Porsche is doing this project.
There's so much to learn.

There's so much technology that
can be learned for future
sports cars.
From me, 918 is just too many.

FRANK WALLISER: It's 30%
less than Carrera GT.

CHRIS HARRIS: It's three
times as much.

FRANK WALLISER: We did a lot of
analysis for the markets,

and if you compare to Carrera
GT, ten years ago there was no
Chinese car market.
It has just grown up.
It's 50 million units.
Also super sports cars.
We have wealthy people there.

We have a total gross in the
automotive market, I think 918
pieces is maybe not enough.

We will have, the demand will be
higher, but we have to have

it limited, and, well, it's
definitely for the first
buyers, a good choice.

No problem in selling
these cars.

CHRIS HARRIS: You heard it
there, boys and girls.

It's been a really interesting
day, and to get access to it
so early has been fascinating.

FRANK WALLISER: Good to
have you in the car.

CHRIS HARRIS: Cheating
physics.
Cheating physics.
Cheers, man.

I'd be lying if I said a hybrid
sports car which drives

the way the 918 currently
drives isn't profoundly
impressive.

It's a very, very
clever machine.

But even though I
enjoyed driving
it, I'm still skeptical.

A Porsche hypercar should, for
me, be the ultimate driving
experience.
End of.

It shouldn't be hampered by
technology unnecessary for the

business of delivering the
very best for the driver.

Every time I stepped from the
car I was grinning madly.

Then a few minutes later, I was
thinking, oh, what would

it be like without all
those batteries.

You see, I see all of those
intriguing weight-saving

solutions, but I want
to feel them in the
1,100 kilogram package.

But the biggest worry for
Porsche must be the McLaren
and the Ferrari.

They appear to have moved into
a different performance

territory by adopting
[INAUDIBLE]
technology to reduce weight.

In a marketplace dominated by
ultimates, the 918, for all

its mind-boggling technology,
risks being the slowest hybrid

hypercar in its class,
and I think that's a
big problem for Porsche.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Driving the 887hp Porsche 918 Spyder - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
People are talking about power to weight as if it's relevant in this 
because there are plenty of cars with better power to weight , um gumpert 
Apollo S anyone? And this thing made the Apollo look like a prius on 
nurburg. So﻿

balanced HyperCar that despite being heavier and less powered than its 
rivals can still lap the Nurburgring the fastest! ﻿
comments.author: Ericship 111™

comments.text:
+Schwanzel Stock lol who told him that? How about that cars like the GTR 
with low power to weigh for its class still eats cars above its class? The 
918 has a lower power to weight then a few cars even 3/4 years ago, yet 
it's light years quicker.. power to weight isn't everything
comments.author: matthew von

comments.text:
+Ericship 111™ Who told you that? Weight and weight distribution is always 
damn important for fast (racing) cars especially when it comes to 
cornering. Power delivery seems to be perfect in the 918 its quicker than 
the P1 to 100km/h
comments.author: Schwanzel Stock

comments.text: Driving the 887hp Porsche 918 Spyder - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS﻿
comments.author: Joshua Seymour (Wade Novian)

comments.text: I agree...... dump the electric motors!!!!﻿
comments.author: dodootjes

comments.text: the nismo backpack in the back ground in the interview at  11.06 :D﻿
comments.author: fdeer

comments.text:
at 8:48 watch the top of the car something flies off of it and lands on the 
ground... what is that?﻿
comments.author: Ramy Warda

comments.text: It didn't come of the car it's rubber from tires
comments.author: Hariz Hafi

comments.text:
As much as I think this is a great car, I just don't see the logic people 
are using to knock the P1.  Compared to the P1, the 918 is inferior in 
power, weight, stance, and aerodynamics, and the steering is heavier.  In 
it's favor it does have all-wheel-drive.  In the one video where they are 
compared for time on a track, the 918 won only when the 918 had "sticky" 
tires and the P1 had what everyone involved agreed were less than ideal 
tires.  When the P1 was outfitted with decent tires (a more fair 
comparison) it pretty much obliterated the time posted by the 918.  

Also, the 918 that is raced on the track is not the same version of 918 
that most people will have on the road.  With the McLaren P1 they are the 
same car.

I have never driven either car but from the videos I have watched a common 
theme seems to be that the 918 is very impressive and the P1 is mind 
blowing.

Anyways, I think both are awesome cars that I will never own.﻿
comments.author: Jefferson Smith

comments.text:
+Pablo Hablántes Doesn't matter Porsche 918 is 3rd fastest on the RING for 
time and still holds fastest STREET LEGAL time, fast production time, and 
many other records.
comments.author: robert Horsch

comments.text: You are mistaken
comments.author: Pablo Hablántes

comments.text:
The tires the P1 used aren't street legal if I'm not mistaken and in race 
mode it definitely isn't street legal. The 918 used sticky tires, yes. But, 
they were road legal. The cars need to be compared with similar tires and 
the P1 shouldn't be in race mode. Also, how do you mean "the 918 that is 
raced on the track is not the same version of 918 that most people will 
have on the road". If you're talking about the weissach pack, it's an 
option many owners have specified.
comments.author: Nick

comments.text:
+Jefferson Smith Haha, fucking idiot. The 918 is much faster up to 100mph, 
it's luxuirous and economical. The P1 is no where near as good.

comments.text:
Too bad you can't call me an idiot to my face keyboard warrior.  We would

comments.author: Jefferson Smith

comments.text:

exactly as it is when sold, the 1 had a non road legal suspension and 2 
attempts..idiot.

comments.text:

a year to do it, there would of been a few perfect days in that year but 
neither of them have done it yet.  So far the only reason give is "oh we 
dont want to"

comments.text:

not sure it is a fact that other production cars can't or haven't beat it. 
 Your mileage may vary.

comments.text:

following you on the times you refer to.  Sorry.

comments.text:

legal track time and 3rd place on the RING right? Out of all the hybrid 
cars no other is in this cars playing field (918) on and off the track.
comments.author: robert Horsch

comments.text:

you could afford almost any car you want, but you would be losing out on 
other things. I'm just talking about having a relatively "normal" paying 
job between "
$100- 150k a year in u.s money

comments.author: Pablo Hablántes

comments.text:
Well said, except for the part about you never owning one. At least not 
with that attitude you won't haha! But about the P1 bashers, there are *a 
lot* of die-hard Porsche fans out there who hate the thought of any of this 
car's competitors actually beating this one out.
comments.author: John Keyes

comments.text:
I give alot of respect to what he just said at 11:20! We only tell the 
figures when we have proven them. Not like Hennessey who claimed to go 275 
mph with their Venom GT before the car was even finished or Koenigsegg who 
claimed 270+ mph but never proved it.﻿
comments.author: PorscheSweden

comments.text: I heard it has a lousy cup holder.﻿
comments.author: Ed Baker

comments.text:
I honestly think that the only car reviews that I can trust are the ones 
done by Hot Version International. ﻿
comments.author: Dashel Perera

comments.text: Hello Moto!﻿
comments.author: Manny Anthou

comments.text:
All I want to see is an Official P1 Lap Time then we can stop the madness 
of assumptions for times that don't officially exist. That's all i want for 
Christmas!!! ﻿
comments.author: Dezz D

comments.text:
Paradox it is with the weight saving and heavy batteries putting in. But 
without it's no hybrid﻿
comments.author: SmashGamez.com - Free 3D online games!

comments.text: Body styling is superb.﻿
comments.author: Paul Davis

comments.text: If i could, i would fuck this car ﻿
comments.author: #Free Gucci

comments.text: it sounds and shifts just like the 458 Italia. ﻿
comments.author: vtecnegro85

comments.text:
Here's food for thought: 1,640kg with 887hp, that's 1.84kg/hp. If what was 
stated in the video was true and the car without all of the electronic crap 
would weigh only 1,100kg and still had 610hp, then you're looking at 
1.80kg/hp. So unless I've gone horribly wrong in my math somewhere, this 
car would potentially be FASTER without all of the electronics, at least 
going purely off of power to weight ratio. Also, with tires and brakes the 
same, this fantasy non-hybrid version would hold better lateral G's and 
brake in a shorter distance.﻿
comments.author: misegades

comments.text:
Having worked for several years for a hybrid/electric vehicle manufacturer, 
I know quite well the advantages of electric motors. However, the fact 
remains that weight is weight, and less weight on a fast car is always 
better. Given the same tires, your grip is improved, given the same brakes, 
your braking is improved, and to get the same acceleration performance less 
power is required.
comments.author: misegades

comments.text:
You must know nothing about electric motors and why they used them in this 
car, proof that they work is its laptimes
comments.author: matthew von

comments.text:
The other thing to remember, and I'm no expert so I may be missing 
something here, is the 'instant torque' from the electric motor. It's not 
just power to weight but also the delivery of that power. Either way, I'd 
love to see a non electric version.
comments.author: Joseph Ellis

comments.text:
+Dezz D it's a fair question. The neat thing about making a car lighter is 
that, generally speaking, if the all else remains unchanged, such as brakes 
and tires, your stopping distance improves, your acceleration improves, and 
your corning improves, both in holding lateral g's, as well as rapidity of 
change in direction. As for how the car would drive differently sans 
electrics, I imagine a little more "raw" since it doesn't have quite as 
much mass to dampen things down, and acceleration might be slightly less 
linear feeling as you pull through the rev range because a combustion 
engine will never be able to deliver the type of torque curve that an 
electric motor can. I imagine it would be an exhilarating ride, even more 
brutally fast than the car already is, and it would probably feel even more 
alive and responsive.
comments.author: misegades

comments.text:
Question, it would potentially be faster (in a straight line) but how would 
it then behave around curves, braking, feel under your butt, would it be a 
handful to control, etc. I am only asking because these variables do play 
in when you start messing with the weight of a car. :)
comments.author: Dezz D

comments.text:
haha who would think that this porsche actually turned out as the fastest 
production car ever built by humans with a staggering 6:57 min on the 
nordschleife being quicker than the p1 and and the laferrari﻿
comments.author: headshooter44

comments.text:
+TEH KOTAK

comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+TEH KOTAK
as porsche and nissan with the GTR clearly demonstrated weight is not a 
limiting factor. yes, you might be a few seconds slower because of the 
weight but that weight is not dead weight. thos heavy components have a 
purpose that makes up the few seconds by far. torque vectoring and 
intelligent chassy dynamics outweigh the added weight in both of those cars 
(GTR and 918) making them the fastest in their class. everyone was also 
saying the same shit about the GTR but you cant deny those lap times. the 
GTR is faster than most supercars and even some hyper cars despite the fact 
that it has 4 seats and a big trunk :D
the special ingredient is magic... excuse me i meant technology thou the 
are both the same nowerdays. thats why you cant compare cars just by 
looking at the numbers. that shit worked on cars 3 years ago but not 
anymore.

now imagine what the 918 would be capable to do with 300 kg less weight, 
wheying the same as a P1 or Laferrari. it would absolutely destroy them by 
at least 10 seconds on the nordschleife! :D

comments.author: Hariz Hafi

comments.text:
As long as Ferrari and McLaren dont give us an official lap time the 918 is 
the fastest production car on track. I think if it would be so easy for 
McLaren and Ferrari to beat the Porsche, like many "experts" say, they 
would have done it. But instead they just began to say right after the 
Porsches time, that it is too dangerous to make hot laps there. Somewhere a 
physical limit is reached and you cant pass this limit just with more 
horsepower. I think all of them are maxed out. I wouldnt say that there are 
Big differences on track. But I havent driven one of them so its just my 
theory. Probably nobody or just a few of the commenters who say that the 
Porsche/Ferrari/McLaren is faster than the other two cars actually drove 
one of these.﻿

and has nothing else to say, they are in the books.  :)

I don't think the P1 will beat the 918 on the ring cause the battery will

designed so that you get the power coming out of every corner cause of the 
way the Formula one energy recovery system works. So Laferrari has a good 
chance to take the ring time. Plus they have the FXX and evolution model 
that there new Halo car was designed from and both those can run sub 7 min 
no problem. Only time will tell

comments.text:
Im with you now! I didnt quite follow the context of what you were pointing 
out, i thought you were saying 'Titanium being lighter than Aluminium' as 
your own observation which is not the case, you were merely pointing out 
his silly comment!! So yes, youre completely right, his comment does seem 
rather odd....i had a 'debate' shall we say with a young lad who was more 
than adament that Ti is lighter than Alu and when the facts were delivered 
just became abusive and obnoxious...glad it wasnt another one of those 
situations. I just apologise for misunderstanding your comment mate
comments.author: Kris Nash

comments.text:
Yes, exactly. Ti Z=22, Al Z=11.
He comments that aluminium would be too heavy, then at 1'48" says it feels 
lighter like light titanium (which as you correctly point out is roughly 
double the density of Aluminium), I do realise it's bonded with carbon 
fibre but the statement still makes no sense - it implies that titanium is 
lighter than aluminium.
comments.author: N Lyndley

comments.text:
Hate to break it to you mate but you seem to be the misinformed party 
here.... Titanium has a higher specific density than Aluminium ultimately 
resulting in it weighing more for a given volumetric mass

hybrid supercar which unlike the system in McLaren and Ferrari, adds a lot

think Porsche are gambling on 918 customers who are very eco-conscious.  ﻿

comments.text:
+Sage God Madara on every site (wikipedia, the official mclaren page) 
stands the production car is 1490kg. funny thing: the production version 
was slower in every single test compared to the prototype. it has 20hp 
more, yes that will make the difference lol^^ therefore the porsche has 
280nm more^^
the aero is more, therefore only 2 wheels are driven, the porsche has 4 
wheel torque vectoring, drive and steering, the better balanced chassis and 
the better calibration/power handling (a thing that porsche is known for 
for over 50 years now^^ that's also why a gt3 with 475hp is faster round a 
handling track than a mp4 12c which is 170hp more powerful and 100kg less)

ah and to the thing chris harris said: on autocars test in england 
(production version) it was 18 seconds to 180mph and 21.4 to 190mph, which 
is actually slower than what various testers (sportauto, auto zeitung) got 
from the 918 weissach package version (they got 18.5 and 19.1 to 186mph)

comments.author: eichler721

comments.text:
u know what, i just wanna stop this arguement. Ok, the Ferrari has the most 
power, but when it comes to tech and handling, you have to give it to 
porsche. The Porsche 918 Spyder has a top speed of over 215MPH and has 
887BHP. But, the thing that separates the porsche from the competition is 
that it has 94MPG, which is more than two priuses combined. Also, Porsche 
practically made the most powerful V-8 engine ever built. They also have a 
dual-PDK transmission which is the most insane transmission ever. It also 
has the best exhaust ever, with the shortest pipes, letting exhaust flow. 
Lastly, BOTH wheels turn for better traction when racing and a tighter 
turning circle when making a u-turn or something. So, in conclusion, 
Ferrari Laferrari has more power and the Porsche 918 Spyder w/wo Wessiach 
Package has better acceleration 0-60 and better tech.





P.S. (U gotta admit the Laferrari name sucks. Like seriously, i think they 
ran out of names so they used the brand name lol)
comments.author: Jude Chacko (Jccspeed)

before).

comments.author: jamietherooster

comments.text:
my opinion is that the 918's all wheel steering and all wheel drive make up 
for the weight , i think the p1 will be the fastest of them all , since its 
downforce is so stratospheric , the 918 will be second not by much , and 
the laferrari will be the one with "the most emotion" , as journalists like 
to say.﻿
comments.author: jamietherooster

comments.text:
Good points. The problem is: You believe everything McLaren says ("the down 
force will be stratospheric"). And up until this point, you can't believe 
anything Macca says. Lol. I take what they say with a grain of salt.

The Porsche will be faster in a myriad of ways (0-60, 1/4 mil, The Ring, 
transitions, etc.). The P1 should be faster in straight line top speed 
above 160mph. But Porsche's working on that right now as well. 

Who knows with the LaFe? But maybe it's better that way (to keep  quiet, 
though we all heard much negative news the past few months on that vehicle)?
comments.author: MSL525

the big three (hybrids)? lol﻿
